summary: This is an internal email chain from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (SDNY) regarding preparations for a briefing for the Attorney General on the investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's death. It includes a draft summary of the investigation's findings, which determined that two MCC correctional officers failed to conduct required checks and falsified records on the night of Epstein's death, and that Epstein was left without a cellmate contrary to policy.

events.title: Discovery of Jeffrey Epstein's Body
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein's body was discovered at approximately 6:30 a.m. in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC). The medical examiner determined he died within the preceding three hours.

events.title: Night of Failed Checks
events.description: Two correctional officers assigned to the Special Housing Unit (SHU) failed to conduct required institutional counts and most required rounds throughout the night and early morning. They falsified records to show they had performed these duties.

events.title: AG Briefing Preparation
events.description: Internal SDNY emails discuss preparing a briefing for the Attorney General on the investigation into Epstein's death, including a one-pager with photos of AUSAs and a summary of findings.

locations: U.S. Attorneys Office for the Southern District of New York, One St. Andrew's Plaza, New York, New York 10007
New York City Office of the Chief Medical Examiner
keyFacts: The SDNY/FBI/DOJ-OIG investigation determined two MCC correctional officers failed to conduct any required counts or most required rounds on the night of August 9-10, 2019, and falsified records to show they had.
Epstein was left without a cellmate from the morning of August 9 until his death, contrary to MCC policy and a specific directive from the Chief Psychologist and then-Warden.
Epstein's body was discovered around 6:30 a.m. on August 10, and the medical examiner estimated time of death within the three hours prior.
The investigation involved over 40 witness interviews (27 MCC employees, 16 inmates), review of video, records, and cellphone searches.
The document is an internal email preparing a briefing for the Attorney General, indicating high-level DOJ oversight of the death investigation.
